Summer Budget 2015: Time will tell
Our analysis of the Summer Budget seeks to provide insight and opinion into what Government policy means for our industry, rather than being a simple reiteration of the key measures.
We found that, although this Budget laid claim to being bold and to putting 'security' first, closer study suggests it may be remembered more for social engineering, and a step in closing the productivity gap, than for fiscal engineering and new infrastructure.
Key issues in and around this Budget include:
-competitive tax measures, such as on VAT and corporation tax, intended to reinforce internationally that the UK is leading the way for global business -a future Roads Fund, but with a significant gap in interim highways funding -a potential reduction in publically funded housing of 4,000 units per year -a statement of intent that at least part of the onus of solving and financing the productivity puzzle will be placed firmly on UK business -a welcome re-prioritisation of Network Rail but no mention of major rail schemes
Despite a big build up, given it is the first truly Conservative Budget in nearly two decades, for our industry too much has been deferred: capital spending, addressing productivity, fiscal reform and planning. We now look forward to what has been billed as a 'rigorous' Spending Review.
